title: The Shout
text:
The Shout is a 1978 British <a href="horror%20film">horror film</a> directed by <a href="Jerzy%20Skolimowski">Jerzy Skolimowski</a>. It was based on a <a href="short%20story">short story</a> by <a href="Robert%20Graves">Robert Graves</a> and adapted for the screen by Michael Austin. The film was the first to be produced by <a href="Jeremy%20Thomas">Jeremy Thomas</a> under his <a href="Recorded%20Picture%20Company">Recorded Picture Company</a> banner.
Premise.
Crossley (<a href="Alan%20Bates">Alan Bates</a>), a mysterious travelling man invades the lives of a young couple, Rachel and Anthony Fielding (<a href="Susannah%20York">Susannah York</a> and <a href="John%20Hurt">John Hurt</a>). Anthony is a composer, who experiments with sound effects and various electronic sources in his secluded <a href="Devon">Devon</a> studio. The couple provides hospitality to Crossley but his intentions are gradually revealed as more sinister. He claims he has learned from an <a href="Indigenous%20Australians">Aboriginal</a> <a href="shaman">shaman</a> how to produce a "terror shout" that can kill anyone who hears it unprotected.
Production.
Interiors were shot at <a href="Pinewood%20Studios">Pinewood Studios</a>, the film's sets were designed by the <a href="art%20director">art director</a> <a href="Simon%20Holland">Simon Holland</a>. The North Devon coastline, specifically <a href="Saunton%20Sands">Saunton Sands</a> and <a href="Braunton%20Burrows">Braunton Burrows</a>, was used for the bulk of the <a href="location%20shooting">location shooting</a>. The church of St Peter in Westleigh Bideford was used for the church scenes. The producer, Jeremy Thomas, later remembered his experience making the film,
The soundtrack is by <a href="Mike%20Rutherford">Michael Rutherford</a> and <a href="Tony%20Banks%20%28musician%29">Tony Banks</a> of the rock band <a href="Genesis%20%28band%29">Genesis</a>. The central theme "From the Undertow" features on Banks's album "<a href="A%20Curious%20Feeling">A Curious Feeling</a>".
Accolades.
The film was nominated for the <a href="Palme%20d%27Or">Palme d'Or</a> at the <a href="1978%20Cannes%20Film%20Festival">1978 Cannes Film Festival</a> and received the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20%28Cannes%20Film%20Festival%29">Grand Prize of the Jury</a>, in a tie with "<a href="Bye%20Bye%20Monkey">Bye Bye Monkey</a>".
In popular culture.
In "<a href="The%20Guard%20%282011%20film%29">The Guard</a>" (2011), Sergeant Boyle (<a href="Brendan%20Gleeson">Brendan Gleeson</a>) is seen watching "The Shout" on television.
